thread.title: Waukegan police gang unit raids net arrests, guns and drugs
thread.title_full: Waukegan police gang unit raids net arrests, guns and drugs

title: Waukegan police gang unit raids net arrests, guns and drugs
text:
Waukegan police gang unit raids net arrests, guns and drugs Handout / HANDOUT Francisco Rodriguez - Original Credit: News-Sun Francisco Rodriguez - Original Credit: News-Sun (Handout / HANDOUT) Staff report 
The Waukegan Police Department's Gang Intelligence Unit raided two homes Thursday, making two arrests and recovering firearms, drugs and money, according to a statement released Friday. 
The two raids, executed after search warrants were obtained, involved separate, unrelated investigations, the statement reported. 
Police report that at about 1:40 p.m., detectives from the gang unit entered a single-family residence in the 1600 block of 13th Street in connection with a weapons investigation. 
Two brothers who lived in the home were arrested during the raid, in which detectives seized more than 400 grams of cannabis, a small amount of cocaine, unprescribed Xanax and a shotgun during a search, according to police. 
Francisco Rodriguez, 23, was charged with unlawful possession of a controlled substance, unlawful possession of cannabis, unlawful possession of cannabis with intent to deliver and not having a firearm owner identification card, police said, adding that he was out of custody on bail Friday with a court appearance scheduled March 17. 
The statement added that 20-year-old Oscar Rodriguez was also arrested. He was charged with unlawful possession of a controlled substance and also was out of jail on bail Friday, according to police. He also has a March 17 court date, officials said. 
In a second raid, which took place about 3 p.m., detectives executed a second search warrant on a single-family home on the 1500 block of 10th Street in connection with a narcotics investigation. 
No one was home when officers entered the residence, but detectives seized more than 500 grams of cannabis, a Glock handgun with an extended capacity magazine, a second handgun, and more than $20,000 believed to be related to drug sales, authorities said, adding that ammunition for the guns was also located in the residence. 
Police said arrest warrants and charges may be pending in connection with the second raid.
